module.name: GraphMath
module.short: A set of mathematical helper routines to simply cross-platform canvas drawing.

descr.p: graphmath.pp contains math helper routines for use for graphics drawing. It is used to simply cross-platform canvas drawing operations. graphmath.pp is part of the LazUtils package.

element.name: TFloatPoint
element.short: TFloatPoint is an extended precision record specifying the X and Y coordinates of a point in a graphic environment.

element.name: TFloatPoint.X
element.short: Horizontal position for the coordinate.

element.name: TFloatPoint.Y
element.short: Vertical position for the coordinate.

element.name: TBezier
element.short: Array type used to store the coordinates for Bezier control points as floating point values.

descr.p: TBezier allows up to 4 coordinates to be specified which represent the control points for the parametric curve. Each coordinate is implemented using the TFloatPoint type, and stored as elements in the array.
TBezier is the type returned by the Bezier function. The type is passed as an argument to routines like: Arc2Bezier, Bezier2Polyline, BezierMidPoint, and SplitBezier.

element.name: PPoint
element.short: Pointer to the TPoint type.

element.name: Angles2Coords
element.short: Converts an Eccentric Angle and an Angle-Length, into the coordinates for the Start and End radial Points.

descr.p: Use Angles2Coords to convert an Eccentric (Radial) angle and an angle-length, such as are used in X-Windows and GTK, into the coordinates for the Start and End radial Points. Like those used in the Arc, Pie, and Chord routines from the Windows API.
The angles are specified in 1/16th of a degree. For example, a full circle equals 5760 (16*360).
Positive values in Angle and AngleLength mean counter-clockwise, while negative values mean clockwise direction. Zero degrees is at the 3 o'clock position.

element.name: Arc2Bezier
element.short: Converts an Arc and ArcLength into a Bezier Approximation of the Arc.

descr.p: Use Arc2Bezier to convert an Arc and ArcLength into a Bezier approximation of the Arc. The Rotation parameter accepts a Rotation-Angle for a rotated Ellipse. For a non-rotated ellipse this value would be 0, or 360. If the AngleLength is greater than 90 degrees, or is equal to 0, it automatically exits, as Bezier cannot accurately approximate any angle greater then 90 degrees, and in fact for best result no angle greater than 45 should be converted, instead an array of Bezier's should be created, each Bezier describing a portion of the total arc no greater than 45 degrees.
The angles are specified in 1/16th of a degree. For example, a full circle equals 5760 (16*360).
Positive values in Angle and AngleLength mean counter-clockwise while negative values mean clockwise direction. Zero degrees is at the 3 o'clock position.

element.name: Bezier
element.short: Gets a TBezier instance representing the specified Bezier control points.

element.name: Bezier.Result
element.short: TBezier instance with the values in C1, C2, C3, and C4.

element.name: Bezier.C1
element.short: Control point on the parametric curve. C1 is an endpoint.

element.name: Bezier.C2
element.short: Control point on the parametric curve. C2 is a directional control point for a Quadratic or Cubic Bezier.

element.name: Bezier.C3
element.short: Control point on the parametric curve. C3 is a directional control point for a Cubic Bezier.

element.name: Bezier.C4
element.short: Control point on the parametric curve. C4 is an endpoint.

element.name: Bezier2Polyline
element.short: Bezier2Polyline - convert a 4-Point Bezier into a Pointer Array of TPoint and a Count variable.

descr.p: Use BezierToPolyline to convert a 4-Point Bezier into a Pointer Array of TPoint and a Count variable which can then be used within either a Polyline, or Polygon routine. It is primarily for use within PolyBezier2Polyline.

If Points is not initialized or Count is less then 0, it is set to nil and the array starts at 0, otherwise it tries to append points to the array starting at Count. Points should ALWAYS be Freed when done by calling to ReallocMem(Points, 0) or FreeMem.

element.name: BezierArcPoints
element.short: BezierArcPoints - convert an Arc and ArcLength into a Pointer Array of TPoints for use with Polyline or Polygon.

descr.p: Use BezierArcPoints to convert an Arc and ArcLength into a Pointer Array of TPoints for use with Polyline or Polygon. The Rotation parameter accepts a Rotation-Angle for a rotated Ellipse. For a non-rotated ellipse this value would be 0, or 360. The result is an Approximation based on 1 or more Beziers.

If the AngleLength is greater than 90 degrees, it calls PolyBezierArcPoints, otherwise it Converts the angles into a Bezier by calling to Arc2Bezier, and then converts the Bezier into an array of Points by calling to Bezier2Polyline.
The angles are specified in 1/16th of a degree. For example, a full circle equals 5760 (16*360).
Positive values in Angle and AngleLength mean counter-clockwise while negative values mean clockwise direction. Zero degrees is at the 3 o'clock position.

If Points is not initialized or Count is less then 0, it is set to nil and the array starts at 0, otherwise it tries to append points to the array starting at Count. Points should ALWAYS be Freed when done by calling ReallocMem(Points, 0) or FreeMem.

element.name: BezierMidPoint
element.short: BezierMidPoint - get the Mid-Point of any 4-Point Bezier. It is primarily for use in SplitBezier.

element.name: CenterPoint
element.short: CenterPoint - get the Center-Point of any rectangle. It is primarily for use with, and in, other routines such as Quadrant, and RadialPoint.

element.name: CalculateLeftTopWidthHeight
element.short: Calculates the values for the output variables in Left, Top, Width, and Height.

descr.p: CalculateLeftTopWidthHeight checks values in the X1, X2, Y1, and Y2 arguments and sets the values for the Left, Top, Width, and Height output parameters accordingly.

dl.dd: Set to the smaller of the two values in X1 and X2.
Set to the difference between the X1 and X2 values. The value will be a positive integer value or zero (0).
Set to the smaller of the two values in Y1 and Y2.
Set to the difference between Y1 and Y2. The value will be a positive integer value or zero (0).

descr.p: Used in the implementation of the Rectangle and Ellipse routines for the GTK widgetset.

element.name: CalculateLeftTopWidthHeight.X1
element.short: Horizontal coordinate examined in the routine.

element.name: CalculateLeftTopWidthHeight.Y1
element.short: Vertical coordinate examined in the routine.

element.name: CalculateLeftTopWidthHeight.X2
element.short: Horizontal coordinate examined in the routine.

element.name: CalculateLeftTopWidthHeight.Y2
element.short: Vertical coordinate examined in the routine.

element.name: CalculateLeftTopWidthHeight.Left
element.short: Returns the left coordinate for the specified values.

element.name: CalculateLeftTopWidthHeight.Top
element.short: Returns the top coordinate for the specified values.

element.name: CalculateLeftTopWidthHeight.Width
element.short: Returns the width for the specified horizontal coordinates.

element.name: CalculateLeftTopWidthHeight.Height
element.short: Returns the height for the specified vertical coordinates.

element.name: Coords2Angles
element.short: Coords2Angles - convert the coords for Start and End Radial- Points into an Eccentric counter clockwise Angle and an Angle-Length.

descr.p: Use Coords2Angles to convert the coords for Start and End Radial-Points, such as are used in the Windows API Arc Pie and Chord routines, into an Eccentric (aka Radial) counter clockwise Angle and an Angle-Length, such as are used in X-Windows and GTK.
The angles angle1 and angle2 are returned in 1/16th of a degree. For example, a full circle equals 5760 (16*360).
Zero degrees is at the 3 o'clock position.

element.name: Distance
element.short: Get the Distance between any two Points. It is primarily for use in other routines such as EccentricAngle.

element.name: EccentricAngle
element.short: EccentricAngle - get the Eccentric Angle of a given point on any non-rotated ellipse.

descr.p: Use EccentricAngle to get the Eccentric( aka Radial ) Angle of a given point on any non-rotated ellipse. It is primarily for use in Coords2Angles. The result is in 1/16th of a degree. For example, a full circle equals 5760 (16*360). Zero degrees is at the 3 o'clock position.

element.name: EllipseRadialLength
element.short: EllipseRadialLength - Radial-Length of non-rotated ellipse at any given Eccentric Angle.

descr.p: Use EllipseRadialLength to get the Radial-Length of non-rotated ellipse at any given Eccentric( aka Radial ) Angle. It is primarily for use in other routines such as RadialPoint. The Eccentric angle is in 1/16th of a degree. For example, a full circle equals 5760 (16*360). Zero degrees is at the 3 o'clock position.

element.name: FloatPoint
element.short: FloatPoint - it is essentially like Classes.Point in use, except that it accepts Extended Parameters. It is Primarily for use with and in Bezier routines.

element.name: LineEndPoint
element.short: LineEndPoint - get the End-Point of a line of any given Length at any given angle with any given Start-Point.

descr.p: Use LineEndPoint to get the End-Point of a line of any given Length at any given angle with any given Start-Point. It is primarily for use in other routines such as RadialPoint. The angle is in 1/16th of a degree. For example, a full circle equals 5760 (16*360). Zero degrees is at the 3 o'clock position.

element.name: MakeMinMax
element.short: Ensures that the i1 argument is the smaller of the two Integer values.

descr.p: MakeMinMax swaps the values in i1 and i2 variable parameters when i1 is larger than i2. No actions are performed in the routine if i1 is smaller than i2, or the arguments have the same value.

element.name: MakeMinMax.i1
element.short: Integer value compared (and potentially updated) in the routine.

element.name: MakeMinMax.i2
element.short: Integer value compared (and potentially updated) in the routine.

element.name: MoveRect
element.short: Moves the specified rectangle to the origin in the x and y arguments.

descr.p: MoveRect sets the Left and Top members in ARect to the values specified in x and y (respectively). The Right and Bottom members in ARect are updated to reflect the relative distance from the original Top and Left on entry.

element.name: MoveRect.ARect
element.short: TRect instance updated in the routine.

element.name: MoveRect.x
element.short: New position for the Top coordinate in the rectangle.

element.name: MoveRect.y
element.short: New position for the Left coordinate in the rectangle.

element.name: MoveRectToFit
element.short: Moves and potentially resizes a rectangle to fit within the specified target rectangle.

descr.p: ARect is the TRect instance repositioned in the routine. Values in the Left, Right, Top, and Bottom members may be updated in the routine if the rectangle is not located within the bounds for the target rectangle.

MaxRect is the TRectangle instance where ARect is repositioned. It also establishes the maximum size for ARect after it has been repositioned. If aRect is larger than MaxRect, ARect is resized to fit with in the constraints in MaxRect.
MoveRectToFit is used in the implementation for the DoDock method in TControl.

element.name: MoveRectToFit.ARect
element.short: TRect instance moved and optionally resized in the routine.

element.name: MoveRectToFit.MaxRect
element.short: TRect instance where the rectangle is relocated. It also specifies the maximum size for the relocated rectangle.

element.name: PolyBezier2Polyline
element.short: PolyBezier2Polyline - convert an array of 4-Point Bezier into a Pointer Array of TPoint and a Count variable.

descr.p: Use BezierToPolyline to convert an array of 4-Point Bezier into a Pointer Array of TPoint and a Count variable which can then be used within either a Polyline, or Polygon routine. Points is automatically initialized, so any existing information is lost, and the array starts at 0. Points should ALWAYS be Freed when done by calling to ReallocMem(Points, 0).

element.name: PolyBezierArcPoints
element.short: PolyBezierArcPoints - convert an Arc and ArcLength into a Pointer Array of TPoints for use with Polyline or Polygon.

descr.p: Use PolyBezierArcPoints to convert an Arc and ArcLength into a Pointer Array of TPoints for use with Polyline or Polygon. The Rotation parameter accepts a Rotation-Angle for a rotated Ellipse - for a non-rotated ellipse this value would be 0, or 360. The result is an Approximation based on 1 or more Beziers. If the AngleLength is greater than 45 degrees, it recursively breaks the Arc into Arcs of 45 degrees or less, and converts them into Beziers with BezierArcPoints.
The angles are specified in 1/16th of a degree. For example, a full circle equals 5760 (16*360).
Positive values in Angle and AngleLength mean counter-clockwise while negative values mean clockwise direction. Zero degrees is at the 3 o'clock position.
Points is automatically initialized, so any existing information is lost, and the array starts at 0. Points should ALWAYS be Freed when done by calling to ReallocMem(Points, 0).

element.name: Quadrant
element.short: Determine the Quadrant of any point, given the Center.

descr.p: Use Quadrant to determine the Quadrant of any point, given the Center. It is primarily for use in other routines such as EccentricAngle. A result of 1-4 represents the primary 4 quadrants. A result of 5-8 means the point lies on one of the Axis, 5 = -Y Axis, 6 = +X Axis, 7 = +Y Axis, and 8 = -X Axis. A result of -1 means that it does not fall in any quadrant, that is, it is the Center.

element.name: RadialPoint
element.short: Get the RadialPoint at any given Eccentric angle on any non- rotated ellipse.

descr.p: Use RadialPoint to get the Radial-Point at any given Eccentric(aka Radial) angle on any non-rotated ellipse. It is primarily for use in Angles2Coords. The EccentricAngle is in 1/16th of a degree. For example, a full circle equals 5760 (16*360). Zero degrees is at the 3 o'clock position.

element.name: RotatePoint
element.short: Rotates a point around the origin by the specified angle (in radians).

descr.p: Rotates a point around the origin (0,0) by the angle in AAngle. The angle is in radians and positive for counter-clockwise rotation. Note that y points downwards.

element.name: RotatePoint.Result
element.short: TPoint with the coordinates after rotation.

element.name: RotatePoint.APoint
element.short: TPoint with coordinates rotated in the routine.

element.name: RotatePoint.AAngle
element.short: Rotation angle in radians.

element.name: RotateRect
element.short: Rotates a rectangle with the specified dimensions by the specified angle (in radians).

descr.p: Rotates the rectangle (0, 0, AWidth, AHeight) around its top-left corner (0,0) by the angle in AAngle (in radians). Note that y points downwards.

element.name: RotateRect.Result
element.short: The smallest TRect which contains the rotated rectangle.

element.name: RotateRect.AWidth
element.short: Width for the rectangle.

element.name: RotateRect.AHeight
element.short: Height for the rectangle.

element.name: RotateRect.AAngle
element.short: Rotation angle in radians.

element.name: SplitBezier
element.short: SplitBezier - split any 4-Point Bezier into two 4-Point Beziers: a 'Left' and a 'Right'

descr.p: Use SplitBezier to split any 4-Point Bezier into two 4-Point Beziers: a 'Left' and a 'Right'. It is primarily for use in Bezier2Polyline.

element.name: add(TFloatPoint,TFloatPoint):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Add operator (+) for values using the TFloatPoint type.

descr.p: Values for the X and Y members in the addends are summed and stored in the corresponding members in the TFloatPoint result.

element.name: add(TFloatPoint,Extended):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Add operator (+) for values using the TFloatPoint and Extended types.

descr.p: The Extended value is added to both the X and Y members in the TFloatPoint type and used in the result for the operator.

element.name: add(Extended,TFloatPoint):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Add operator (+) for values using the Extended and TFloatPoint types.

descr.p: The Extended value is added to both the X and Y members in the TFloatPoint type and used in the result for the operator.

element.name: add(TFloatPoint,TPoint):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Add operator (+) for values using the TFloatPoint and TPoint types.

element.name: add(TPoint,TFloatPoint):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Add operator (+) for values using the TPoint and TFloatPoint types.

element.name: subtract(TFloatPoint,Extended):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Subtract operator (-) for values using the TFloatPoint and Extended types.

descr.p: The value in the Extended type is subtracted from both the X and Y members in the TFloatPoint type and used in the result for the operator.

element.name: subtract(TFloatPoint,TFloatPoint):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Subtract operator (-) for values using the TFloatPoint type.

element.name: subtract(TFloatPoint,TPoint):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Subtract operator (-) for values using the TFloatPoint and TPoint types.

element.name: subtract(TPoint,TFloatPoint):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Subtract operator (-) for values using the TPoint and TFloatPoint types.

element.name: multiply(TFloatPoint,TFloatPoint):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Multiply operator (*) for values using the TFloatPoint type.

element.name: multiply(TFloatPoint,Extended):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Multiply operator (*) for values using the TFloatPoint and Extended types.

descr.p: The value in the Extended type is applied to both the X and Y members in the TFloatPoint type and used in the result for the operator.

element.name: multiply(Extended,TFloatPoint):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Multiply operator (*) for values using the Extended and TFloatPoint types.

descr.p: The value in the Extended type is applied to both the X and Y members in the TFloatPoint type and used in the result for the operator.

element.name: multiply(TFloatPoint,TPoint):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Multiply operator (*) for values using the TFloatPoint and TPoint types.

element.name: multiply(TPoint,TFloatPoint):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Multiply operator (*) for values using the TPoint and TFloatPoint types.

element.name: divide(TFloatPoint,TFloatPoint):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Divide operator (/) for values using the TFloatPoint type.

element.name: divide(TFloatPoint,Extended):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Divide operator (/) for values using the TFloatPoint and Extended types.

descr.p: The value in the Extended type is applied to both the X and Y members in the TFloatPoint type and used in the result for the operator. No validation is performed for the divisor in the operator.

element.name: divide(TFloatPoint,TPoint):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Divide operator (/) for values using the TFloatPoint and TPoint types.

element.name: divide(TPoint,TFloatPoint):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Divide operator (/) for values using the TPoint and TFloatPoint types.

element.name: equal(TPoint,TPoint):Boolean
element.short: Implements the Equal operator (=) to compare values using the TPoint type.

descr.p: The result is True when the X and Y members in the compared values are the same.

element.name: equal(TFloatPoint,TFloatPoint):Boolean
element.short: Implements the Equal operator (=) to compare values using the TFloatPoint type.

descr.p: The result is True when the X and Y members in the compared values are the same.

element.name: equal(TRect,TRect):Boolean
element.short: Implements the Equal operator (=) to compare values using the TRect type.

descr.p: The result is True when the Left, Top, Right, and Bottom members in the compared values are the same.

element.name: assign(TFloatPoint):TPoint
element.short: Implements the Assign operator (=) to store a value using the TFloatPoint type to a TPoint instance.

descr.p: SimpleRoundTo in the RTL math.pp unit is called to round both the X and Y members to a Double value with 0 decimals in the precision. The Double values are truncated and stored to the Longint types used for the X and Y members in the result for the operator.

element.name: assign(TPoint):TFloatPoint
element.short: Implements the Assign operator (=) to store a value using the TPoint type to a TFloatPoint instance.

descr.p: This Unit contains a number of routines for calculating and converting series of graphic points from one coordinate system to another.
A fundamental type is introduced, called TFloatPoint. It is an extended precision record containing an X and a Y coordinate for a graphic point. Its structure is as follows:

The Unit contains definitions for mathematical operators which extend the normal definitions of addition, subtraction, multiplication, division and comparison to cover manipulations with TFloatPoints, allowing, for example, addition or multiplication of two TFloatPoints, a TFloatPoint and a TPoint, or a TFloatPoint and an Extended precision number.
